Not all sources are created equal. Like choosing the right weapons for a raid, selecting credible sources is essential for strong research. You must learn to evaluate reliability, relevance, and accuracy.

Your mission? Learn to distinguish between credible and unreliable sources, and understand when different types of sources are appropriate.

Training Scrolls

Evaluating Sources - CRAAP Test:

  • Currency: Is the information recent enough?
  • Relevance: Does it relate to your topic?
  • Authority: Who wrote it? Are they qualified?
  • Accuracy: Can the information be verified?
  • Purpose: Why was it written? Is it biased?

Your Quest Materials

Different Sources - Complete this worksheet

Raid Strategy Guide

Step 1: Understand Source Types

Primary sources = original documents (diaries, interviews)
Secondary sources = analysis of primary sources (textbooks, articles)
Tertiary sources = summaries (encyclopedias, databases)

Step 2: Check the Author

Who wrote this? What are their qualifications? Do they have expertise in this topic?

Step 3: Verify the Publisher

Is this from a reputable organization? Academic journals, established news sources, and .edu/.gov sites are generally more reliable.

Step 4: Look for Bias

Does the source present only one side? Is it trying to sell something or push an agenda? Look for balanced presentation of facts.

Step 5: Check the Date

When was this published? For some topics, recent sources are essential. For historical topics, older sources may be valuable.
